When running the command:


```
#!unix

vcs import . < vmrc.repos
```


I get the following output:


```
#!Unix

=== ./robotx_gazebo (hg) ===
Could not determine url: not found!

#!unix

sudo pip install vcstools

```

I am running Ubuntu 16.04 and had ROS Kinetic installed prior

values.title: Simplify collision for Sandisland

content.raw: As found in #1, the height map based collision for sandisland is very taxing on ray based sensors such as the velodyne_gazebo plugin. This collision is not very important, as the simulation will take place in open water with objects remaining on the surface, so it could just be removed. Alternatively, simple geometries for the shore and sea floor collisions could be implemented.
content.html: As found in #1, the height map based collision for sandisland is very taxing on ray based sensors such as the velodyne_gazebo plugin. This collision is not very important, as the simulation will take place in open water with objects remaining on the surface, so it could just be removed. Alternatively, simple geometries for the shore and sea floor collisions could be implemented.

values.title: Reduce the amount of log information

content.raw:
There's a constant flow of log information:

```
[ INFO] [1530898335.354347581, 5.500000000]: 0: 0.0414236 / 0.000165695
[ INFO] [1530898335.855024332, 6.000000000]: 0: 0.0414236 / 0.000165695
[ INFO] [1530898335.891886977, 6.037000000]: Command timeout!
[ INFO] [1530898336.357305769, 6.501000000]: 0: 0.0414236 / 0.000
```

that deviates the attention from other errors or sporadic log info. We should avoid continuous log messages.

We could either play with the log level or remove these calls to `ROS_INFO_STREAM_THROTTLE()` in `usv_gazebo_thrust_plugin.cc`.

values.title: Coordinate the physics and visualization of the wave field

content.raw:
Currently the visualization of the surface waves is independent of the wave displacements that affect the vessel motion. We have them setup to use the same wave parameters (amplitude, direction, etc.), but they are not synchronized in time.
See a demo of the effect: https://vimeo.com/253718860 And here is what happens if you have large wave in the physics, but the same small waves in the rendering: https://vimeo.com/253842494
content.html: Currently the visualization of the surface waves is independent of the wave displacements that affect the vessel motion. We have them setup to use the same wave parameters (amplitude, direction, etc.), but they are not synchronized in time. See a demo of the effect: https://vimeo.com/253718860 And here is what happens if you have large wave in the physics, but the same small waves in the rendering: https://vimeo.com/253842494

values.title: Acoustic beacon - range and bearing

content.raw:
This is a proposal - would  welcome improvements and comments.

As a first prototype, having the following simple capability would provide teams with a tool to prototype the way their autonomy deals with underwater acoustic beacons used in RobotX.

* Provides a simulated measurement of the range, azimuth and elevation between a specific model link and a fixed point (defined as location in gazebo coordinates)
* with user configured uncertainty in each of the three dimensions
* at a user configured update rate (0.5 - 2 Hz) 

Teams have to develop this functionality using a variety of methods (e.g., hydrophone arrays and beam forming), but we can use a higher abstraction for the purposes of developing autonomy.

The description above is a sufficient first step.  A couple of next-step extensions to increase fidelity, might include

* Uncertainty model should include Gaussian uncertainty, but could also include a probability of an outlier and/or dropout - which is typical of acoustic means.
* Ranges are subject to line-of-sight visibility (probably too detailed for RobotX)
content.html:
This is a proposal - would welcome improvements and comments.

As a first prototype, having the following simple capability would provide teams with a tool to prototype the way their autonomy deals with underwater acoustic beacons used in RobotX.

  • Provides a simulated measurement of the range, azimuth and elevation between a specific model link and a fixed point (defined as location in gazebo coordinates)
  • with user configured uncertainty in each of the three dimensions
  • at a user configured update rate (0.5 - 2 Hz)

Teams have to develop this functionality using a variety of methods (e.g., hydrophone arrays and beam forming), but we can use a higher abstraction for the purposes of developing autonomy.

The description above is a sufficient first step. A couple of next-step extensions to increase fidelity, might include

  • Uncertainty model should include Gaussian uncertainty, but could also include a probability of an outlier and/or dropout - which is typical of acoustic means.
  • Ranges are subject to line-of-sight visibility (probably too detailed for RobotX)

values.title: Add 3D LIDAR support

content.raw:
Add simulation xacro and (if needed) plugins for simulating a 3D scanning LIDAR, similar to a [Velodyne puck](https://velodynelidar.com/vlp-16.html). 

This will be useful for the RobotX teams which use a sensor like this and could be a standard sensor for the virtual competition.

Gazebo7 supports the simulation of sensors like this using the gpu_sensor. For getting this sensor to interface with ROS, there are a few options:

* The [velodyne_simulator](http://wiki.ros.org/velodyne_simulator) contains a plugin to simulate a velodyne, publishing the same output as the real velodyne driver. Downside: somewhat specific to velodyne sensor

* gazebo_ros_block_laser plugin in [gazebo_ros_pkgs](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs). Downsides: publishes the legacy PointCloud message instead of PointCloud2 (which may make it incompatible with some higher level software) and it does NOT support gpu based simulation.

* The gazebo_ros_ray_sensor plugin in my recent [Pull Request to gazebo_ros_pkgs](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/pull/778/files#diff-6450cfd8fcaf96c62b536b1c0225e91d). This provides something similar to gazebo_ros_block_laser but uses the newer message standard and supports either CPU or GPU simulation. Downside: not currently merged (may never be merged into kinetic), so would likely have to import it into this repo
content.html:
Add simulation xacro and (if needed) plugins for simulating a 3D scanning LIDAR, similar to a Velodyne puck.

This will be useful for the RobotX teams which use a sensor like this and could be a standard sensor for the virtual competition.

Gazebo7 supports the simulation of sensors like this using the gpu_sensor. For getting this sensor to interface with ROS, there are a few options:

  • The velodyne_simulator contains a plugin to simulate a velodyne, publishing the same output as the real velodyne driver. Downside: somewhat specific to velodyne sensor

  • gazebo_ros_block_laser plugin in gazebo_ros_pkgs. Downsides: publishes the legacy PointCloud message instead of PointCloud2 (which may make it incompatible with some higher level software) and it does NOT support gpu based simulation.

  • The gazebo_ros_ray_sensor plugin in my recent Pull Request to gazebo_ros_pkgs. This provides something similar to gazebo_ros_block_laser but uses the newer message standard and supports either CPU or GPU simulation. Downside: not currently merged (may never be merged into kinetic), so would likely have to import it into this repo

values.title: Adding Documentation for Sensors with different Thruster Configuration

content.raw:
Hey All, thanks for the great work on the simulation. I just wanted to point out that there was no documentation for utilizing sensors with different thruster configurations. When running:

```
#!unix

roslaunch robotx_gazebo sandisland.launch urdf:=`pwd`/my_wamv.urdf  thrust_config:=X
```
It will run the simulation with the sensors, but the thrust configuration will remain as the default "H" Layout. 
To change this I had to edit wamv_gazebo.urdf.xacro so that the line:

```
#!xacro

<xacro:wamv_gazebo thruster_layout="$(find wamv_gazebo)/urdf/thruster_layouts/wamv_aft_thrusters.xacro"/>
```
instead reads:
```
#!xacro

<xacro:wamv_gazebo thruster_layout="$(find wamv_gazebo)/urdf/thruster_layouts/wamv_x_thrusters.xacro"/>
```
and then converting the xacro to urdf by:

```
#!unix

rosrun xacro xacro --inorder wamv_gazebo.urdf.xacro > wamv_gazebo.urdf

```
 Only after doing this will the command:

```
#!unix

roslaunch robotx_gazebo sandisland.launch urdf:=`pwd`/my_wamv.urdf  thrust_config:=X
```
work as expected

If this documentation was added to the tutorials I think that would help others who are trying to utilize the sensors with the different thrust configurations.

Hey All, thanks for the great work on the simulation. I just wanted to point out that there was no documentation for utilizing sensors with different thruster configurations. When running:

roslaunch robotx_gazebo sandisland.launch urdf:=`pwd`/my_wamv.urdf  thrust_config:=X

It will run the simulation with the sensors, but the thrust configuration will remain as the default "H" Layout. To change this I had to edit wamv_gazebo.urdf.xacro so that the line:

<xacro:wamv_gazebo thruster_layout="$(find wamv_gazebo)/urdf/thruster_layouts/wamv_aft_thrusters.xacro"/>

instead reads:

<xacro:wamv_gazebo thruster_layout="$(find wamv_gazebo)/urdf/thruster_layouts/wamv_x_thrusters.xacro"/>

and then converting the xacro to urdf by:

rosrun xacro xacro --inorder wamv_gazebo.urdf.xacro > wamv_gazebo.urdf

Only after doing this will the command:

roslaunch robotx_gazebo sandisland.launch urdf:=`pwd`/my_wamv.urdf  thrust_config:=X

work as expected

If this documentation was added to the tutorials I think that would help others who are trying to utilize the sensors with the different thrust configurations.

values.title: Refactor Docker Tutorials

content.raw:
Based on Carlos' email comments, would recommend the following refactor for docker tutorials:

  * Install on host: no changes
  * Using Docker:
    * Install Docker (Common setup for all docker use cases)
        * Install Nvidia Docker  (additional instructions for Nvidia users)
    * Two posibilities for using Docker containers
        1. Download and run current Docker image from Docker Hub (includes both non-nvidia and nvidia directions)  Use this option if you want a stable setup with minimal steps to get running, but without the latest changes to the source code.  Best if you are a user and don't plan to contribute to the project.
        2. Build and run Docker image from latest VMRC repository (includes both non-nvidia and nvidia directions)  Use this option if you want your own Docker container with the most recent source code.  Best if you want to contribute to the VMRC project.

    • Two posibilities for using Docker containers
      1. Download and run current Docker image from Docker Hub (includes both non-nvidia and nvidia directions) Use this option if you want a stable setup with minimal steps to get running, but without the latest changes to the source code. Best if you are a user and don't plan to contribute to the project.
      2. Build and run Docker image from latest VMRC repository (includes both non-nvidia and nvidia directions) Use this option if you want your own Docker container with the most recent source code. Best if you want to contribute to the VMRC project.

values.title: Driving and Propulsion Tutorials reference missing xacro file

content.raw:
The driving tutorial  (#!/osrf/vmrc/wiki/tutorials/Driving) describes a "default configuration" that is associated with a wamv_gazebo_thrust_plugin.xacro file. The link to the file (#!/osrf/vmrc/src/default/wamv_gazebo/urdf/dynamics/wamv_gazebo_thrust_plugin.xacro) gives a file not found error. On inspecting the source, it seems that this file has been deprecated and is no longer the default. However, many details of the tutorial still seem to work, so I'm not sure whether the tutorial is still using the configuration it describes or not. If it is, then we should update the link to the correct configuration file. If not, we may need to change the description of the model in the tutorial to match whatever the new default is.

This same problem occurs in the Propulsion Configuration tutorial (#!/osrf/vmrc/wiki/tutorials/PropulsionConfiguration), which has a copy of the same paragraph in it.

It could be just the bullet/number mix, but this explanation lost me. What do we mean by "define new URDF/xacro definition of the WAM-V"?

values.title: build.bash can pass illegal input to Docker tag

content.raw:
Docker tags only support ASCII (see https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/tag/). The build.bash script generates tags using the Linux date command, and the output of the date command varies depending on the locale settings. For some locale settings, such as Chinese, this causes the date command to produce a unicode string, which causes a crash when used as input to the `-t` argument of the `docker build` command.

We can avoid this by choosing a tag format that is ASCII in all locales. One fix is to eliminate the use of `date`. Another is to use formatting options that remain numeric (such as %m instead of %b).
content.html:
Docker tags only support ASCII (see https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/tag/). The build.bash script generates tags using the Linux date command, and the output of the date command varies depending on the locale settings. For some locale settings, such as Chinese, this causes the date command to produce a unicode string, which causes a crash when used as input to the -t argument of the docker build command.

We can avoid this by choosing a tag format that is ASCII in all locales. One fix is to eliminate the use of date. Another is to use formatting options that remain numeric (such as %m instead of %b).

values.title: Set UID and GID of container user at runtime

content.raw:
Currently the Docker image builds with the user "developer" and a UID and GID that matches the person building it. This causes at least two problems:
1) It breaks the automatic build process, since there is no user in the autobuild environment that it can match the UID to.
2) It causes undesirable behavior in cases where the person running the image has a different UID from the person who built it. (See discussion [here](https://boxboat.com/2017/07/25/fixuid-change-docker-container-uid-gid/) and [here](https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/7198)

This problem is widely acknowledged and a fix has been requested but not yet implemented. In the meantime, many workarounds have been proposed. One of the most thorough of these is [fixuid](https://boxboat.com/2017/07/25/fixuid-change-docker-container-uid-gid/), which solves the problem by checking for UID and GID mismatches in a script set to the container entrypoint, then adjusting the internet user's UID and GID to match if necessary, and also scanning the file system to make the necessary file ownership changes.

Although not ideal, this is seems like the best available solution until there is official support for something better.
content.html:
Currently the Docker image builds with the user "developer" and a UID and GID that matches the person building it. This causes at least two problems: 1) It breaks the automatic build process, since there is no user in the autobuild environment that it can match the UID to. 2) It causes undesirable behavior in cases where the person running the image has a different UID from the person who built it. (See discussion here and here

This problem is widely acknowledged and a fix has been requested but not yet implemented. In the meantime, many workarounds have been proposed. One of the most thorough of these is fixuid, which solves the problem by checking for UID and GID mismatches in a script set to the container entrypoint, then adjusting the internet user's UID and GID to match if necessary, and also scanning the file system to make the necessary file ownership changes.

Although not ideal, this is seems like the best available solution until there is official support for something better.

* The goal pose is defined within the associated world file 
    *  Plugin parses the goal pose and publishes the goal as a [GeoPoseStamped](http://docs.ros.org/melodic/api/geographic_msgs/html/msg/GeoPose.html).  Publish with the latch option.
    *  The geographic (lat/lon) position is translated into Gazebo coordinates
* During each simulation update
    * Once the plugin is in "running" state, start scoring
    * Publish
        * 2D Pose error metric that includes yaw?  Something like sqrt(dx^2+dy^2+W(dhdg^2)) 
 where we need to define the weighting “W”. Threshold on max. allowable distance?
        * error (std_msgs/Float64): Current 2D error as sqrt(dx^2+dy^2) in meters
        * Note - will need to convert goal (in lat/lon) to Gazebo coordinates
        * Note - competitors would not have access to this during scored runs!
        * rms (std_msgs/Float64): Cumulative 2D RMS error in meters

values.title: Waypoint Navigation Task

content.raw:
Currently working in the waypoint-navigation-task branch.

Sketch of how the plugin could work.

### Setup
* The USV starts at a random initial pose (lat/lon).
* A series of waypoints are defined with the associated world file.
* Plugin parses the waypoints and publishes them as GeoPoseStamped messages to topic = /vmrc/task/waypoints 
* Publish with the latch option.
* The geographic (lat/lon) positions are translated into Gazebo coordinates

### Running
During each simulation update: 

* Calculate score (Once the plugin is in "running" state)
    * Calculate the 2D pose error between vehicle and all waypoints (metric should match stationkeeping error calculation; currently sqrt(dx^2+dy^2+W(dhdg^2)) where W is not yet determined).
    * Store minimum 2D pose error achieved for each waypoint
    * Score = average minimum 2D pose error for all waypoints
Note - Assuming it is up to the teams to decide the order with which to traverse the waypoints.
* Publish
    * Current minimum pose error for all waypoints?
Note - will need to convert waypoints (in lat/lon) to Gazebo coordinates
Note - competitors would not have access to pose error during scored runs!
    * score (std_msgs/Float64): Mean minimum 2D pose error

values.title: Possible frame error in simulated GPS velocity generation

content.raw:
Hi There,

I have been experimenting with the state estimation in the VRX simulation, and believe I have found a frame error in the generation of velocity information by the simulated GPS sensor.
ROS and Gazebo both appear to use a right-handed East-North-Up coordinate system, defined in [REP-015](http://www.ros.org/reps/rep-0105.html#map) and also specified in the ```spherical_coordinates``` tag of the sand island world.

However, if a wam-v is placed in the VRX world, aligned with the x-axis and driven forwards, the world frame velocity reported by the ```fix_velocity``` topic will be negative y, Similarly, when aligned with the y-axis, the velocity will be positive x.  Examination of the simulated GPS sensor in ```wamv_gps.xacro``` shows that the ```referenceHeading``` tag has been used to rotate the GPS frame to align the latitude and longitude values with the ENU frame.

This may be caused by the way that the underlying hector_gazebo [gps plugin](https://github.com/tu-darmstadt-ros-pkg/hector_gazebo/blob/kinetic-devel/hector_gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_gps.cpp)  operates.  With a zero ```referenceHeading```, the plugin appears to use a North-West-Up frame to generate latitude and longitude.  Rotating this into East-North-Up causes the velocity data to be similarly rotated.

Steps to reproduce;

Select sensor wamv in the ```vmrc.launch``` file, then run the keydrive examples.

```rostopic echo /gps/fix_velocity```

Use keydrive to move the wamv forward.  ```fix_velocity``` should show a negative y value as the largest component.

Rotate the wam-v to align with the y-axis and move the wam-v forward.   ```fix_velocity``` should show a positive x value as the largest component.

Regards,
Jonathan Wheare.
content.html:
Hi There,

I have been experimenting with the state estimation in the VRX simulation, and believe I have found a frame error in the generation of velocity information by the simulated GPS sensor. ROS and Gazebo both appear to use a right-handed East-North-Up coordinate system, defined in REP-015 and also specified in the spherical_coordinates tag of the sand island world.

However, if a wam-v is placed in the VRX world, aligned with the x-axis and driven forwards, the world frame velocity reported by the fix_velocity topic will be negative y, Similarly, when aligned with the y-axis, the velocity will be positive x. Examination of the simulated GPS sensor in wamv_gps.xacro shows that the referenceHeading tag has been used to rotate the GPS frame to align the latitude and longitude values with the ENU frame.

This may be caused by the way that the underlying hector_gazebo gps plugin operates. With a zero referenceHeading, the plugin appears to use a North-West-Up frame to generate latitude and longitude. Rotating this into East-North-Up causes the velocity data to be similarly rotated.

Steps to reproduce;

Select sensor wamv in the vmrc.launch file, then run the keydrive examples.

rostopic echo /gps/fix_velocity

Use keydrive to move the wamv forward. fix_velocity should show a negative y value as the largest component.

Rotate the wam-v to align with the y-axis and move the wam-v forward. fix_velocity should show a positive x value as the largest component.

Regards, Jonathan Wheare.

values.title: Workflow for docker

content.raw:
From @m1chaelm in [PR #74](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/74/merge-dockers/diff#comment-93439791)

'''
Another note about the tutorial: I think the instructions would be much simpler if we just have the user clone the repository. A little more data has to be pulled, but fewer commands are needed. What do you think?
'''

I think there are at least three options...

 1. Leave instructions as-is, were folks `wget` the individual files.  I agree this is clunky.  
 2. Change instructions to clone entire vrx repos.  This has been my habit - makes it easier to work on specific branches, etc.  Downside is it seems inefficient to clone entire repos. for a few small text file.
 3. Create a separate repos with just the docker bits (Dockerfile, build/run scirpts,  etc.)  This seems to be a popular arranges.

I'd vote for 3, but I'm the least experienced with Docker.

content.raw: Users who want to develop in the Docker image would probably prefer not to rebuild the image every time they recompile. There are many ways to do this. One simple option is to use a bind mount in the run command. This tutorial will explain how to get that working.

values.title: Use of gazebo::msgs:Param and Param_V breaks Gazebo 7 support.

content.raw:
This has to do with integrating the new method for synchronized visual and physics wave generation.  Currently this new feature is being developed in the `wave_visualization` branch.

The source of the `wave_gazebo_plugins` package makes use of the Param and Param_V Gazebo messages introduced in Gazebo 8.  (See examples in [Utilities.hh](#!/osrf/vrx/src/wave_visualization/wave_gazebo_plugins/include/wave_gazebo_plugins/Utilities.hh).)  This is used for setting the wave field parameters used by the model and visual plugins via gazebo message.

This seems fine for Gazebo 9, but is not supported in Gazebo 7 or 8.  

Will need to be addressed before merging into default if we are going to maintain Gazebo 7 functionality.
content.html:
This has to do with integrating the new method for synchronized visual and physics wave generation. Currently this new feature is being developed in the wave_visualization branch.

The source of the wave_gazebo_plugins package makes use of the Param and Param_V Gazebo messages introduced in Gazebo 8. (See examples in Utilities.hh.) This is used for setting the wave field parameters used by the model and visual plugins via gazebo message.

This seems fine for Gazebo 9, but is not supported in Gazebo 7 or 8.

Will need to be addressed before merging into default if we are going to maintain Gazebo 7 functionality.

values.title: Addition of stochastic variation to wind model

content.raw:
The [usv_gazebo_wind_plugin](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/usv_gazebo_plugins/include/usv_gazebo_plugins/usv_gazebo_wind_plugin.hh) simulates the influence of wind on a vessel.  Currently a constant wind speed and direction is specified.  The resulting forces and moment are then calculated based on an empirical coefficient-based model as described in the documentation [pdf](https://github.com/bsb808/robotx_docs/blob/master/theoryofoperation/theory_of_operation.pdf).

A more authentic wind model would capture both the mean wind and the variation (gusts, etc.)  Perhaps a first step in this direction is the linear first-order approximation of the Harris spectrum described in the attached pages from Fossen's "Guidance and Control of Ocean Vehicles".  

To start with, only the wind speed should have a stochastic component - the wind direction can be a constant.  The approximated Harris spectrum in the reference includes a "time and gain constant" that are functions of the mean wind speed.  We would want these two parameters to be available to the user so that the relative influence of the mean wind and the variable wind could be independently specified.

Another feature would be to allow for specifying the random seed so that the same variation could be used across multiple runs of the simulation.
content.html:
The usv_gazebo_wind_plugin simulates the influence of wind on a vessel. Currently a constant wind speed and direction is specified. The resulting forces and moment are then calculated based on an empirical coefficient-based model as described in the documentation pdf.

A more authentic wind model would capture both the mean wind and the variation (gusts, etc.) Perhaps a first step in this direction is the linear first-order approximation of the Harris spectrum described in the attached pages from Fossen's "Guidance and Control of Ocean Vehicles".

To start with, only the wind speed should have a stochastic component - the wind direction can be a constant. The approximated Harris spectrum in the reference includes a "time and gain constant" that are functions of the mean wind speed. We would want these two parameters to be available to the user so that the relative influence of the mean wind and the variable wind could be independently specified.

Another feature would be to allow for specifying the random seed so that the same variation could be used across multiple runs of the simulation.

values.title: Color sequence not visible from the cameras

content.raw:
The current implementation of the `light_buoy_plugin` has an important bug because the color pattern cannot be seen from the cameras.

The color sequence is shown from the GUI 3D view but not from the cameras.

This problem happens because we're loading the visual plugin only in the GUI side but not in the server. If we run it in the server, the main issue will be solved but a new issue will appear:

  * If we request a new random sequence, only one of the plugins will receive the call and change the color. At that point, both plugins will have different color sequences, which will be very confusing. This is due to the nature of the ROS services, where only one node will process a service request.

To fix this issue, we could subscribe to a regular message. This way, both plugins will receive the color change request. At this point, we could face a new issue:

* Both plugins might generate a different color sequence. Even if we use a common seed to generate the random sequence, the same combination is not guaranteed. This is because server and GUI are executing different code. 

To fix this issue, we could generate all color patterns, store them in an array and choose the next element of the array whenever the plugin receives a new color request. It will not be truly random but I think it will satisfy the needs of the users in any case.
content.html:
The current implementation of the light_buoy_plugin has an important bug because the color pattern cannot be seen from the cameras.

The color sequence is shown from the GUI 3D view but not from the cameras.

This problem happens because we're loading the visual plugin only in the GUI side but not in the server. If we run it in the server, the main issue will be solved but a new issue will appear:

  • If we request a new random sequence, only one of the plugins will receive the call and change the color. At that point, both plugins will have different color sequences, which will be very confusing. This is due to the nature of the ROS services, where only one node will process a service request.

To fix this issue, we could subscribe to a regular message. This way, both plugins will receive the color change request. At this point, we could face a new issue:

  • Both plugins might generate a different color sequence. Even if we use a common seed to generate the random sequence, the same combination is not guaranteed. This is because server and GUI are executing different code.

To fix this issue, we could generate all color patterns, store them in an array and choose the next element of the array whenever the plugin receives a new color request. It will not be truly random but I think it will satisfy the needs of the users in any case.

values.title: Support the ability to specify task parameters via YAML file.
Wind plugin - adding ROS interface

content.raw:
For the purposes of verifying the implementation and supporting the team’s development, I think it would be helpful to include ROS publication of the instantaneous wind speed and direction.  

* Change the way the wind direction is specified by the user.  Currently specified as a 3D vector in [wamv\_gazebo\_wind\_plugin.xacro](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/wamv_gazebo/urdf/dynamics/wamv_gazebo_wind_plugin.xacro). Since the model is a 2D model it would make more sense to define the wind direction as a single angle.  Would recommend the convention for that angle to be in degrees, defining the direction from which the wind originates in the usual ENU coordinate frame.  E.g., an angle of 0 degrees is a wind that goes from east to west, 90 degrees is a wind that goes from north to south, etc.
* Add a ROS publisher to the wind plugin to report the instantaneous speed and direction

    * Allow user to toggle the ROS publication - default would be to publish, but could be suppressed. 
    * Allow user to specify that update rate of that publication.  Default of publishing each update cycle is overkill, so would be ideal to allow user to throttle the publication rate.
    * Could publish speed and direction as a single custom message, but perhaps a better solution is to publish two separate float messages for speed and direction.
content.html:
For the purposes of verifying the implementation and supporting the team’s development, I think it would be helpful to include ROS publication of the instantaneous wind speed and direction.

  • Change the way the wind direction is specified by the user. Currently specified as a 3D vector in wamv_gazebo_wind_plugin.xacro. Since the model is a 2D model it would make more sense to define the wind direction as a single angle. Would recommend the convention for that angle to be in degrees, defining the direction from which the wind originates in the usual ENU coordinate frame. E.g., an angle of 0 degrees is a wind that goes from east to west, 90 degrees is a wind that goes from north to south, etc.

  • Add a ROS publisher to the wind plugin to report the instantaneous speed and direction

    • Allow user to toggle the ROS publication - default would be to publish, but could be suppressed.
    • Allow user to specify that update rate of that publication. Default of publishing each update cycle is overkill, so would be ideal to allow user to throttle the publication rate.
    • Could publish speed and direction as a single custom message, but perhaps a better solution is to publish two separate float messages for speed and direction.

values.title: Wind plugin random seed specification

content.raw:
To be able to run the competition it is important that the random parts of the environment, for example the stochastic aspects of the wind speed/direction, be repeatable.  This will allow the evaluation of each team’s solution to be done with the same environmental conditions.

Currently the wind plugin exposes “random\_seed” integer to the user which can be used to set the random number generator seed value.

* We should run some tests to verify that this method generates repeatable wind conditions.

Alternatively, Gazebo has[ two methods for setting the seed value.](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=random_numbers&cat=math)  

* Is this feature of gazebo equivalent to setting the seed integer within the plugin?  If so, could/should we simplify the plugin and use the native gazebo feature?
content.html:
To be able to run the competition it is important that the random parts of the environment, for example the stochastic aspects of the wind speed/direction, be repeatable. This will allow the evaluation of each team’s solution to be done with the same environmental conditions.

Currently the wind plugin exposes “random_seed” integer to the user which can be used to set the random number generator seed value.

  • We should run some tests to verify that this method generates repeatable wind conditions.

Alternatively, Gazebo has two methods for setting the seed value.

  • Is this feature of gazebo equivalent to setting the seed integer within the plugin? If so, could/should we simplify the plugin and use the native gazebo feature?

values.title: Determine method for specifying the 'seastate' of the simulation.

content.raw:
For the purposes of the competition we need to be able to specify the wave conditions \(seastate\) in the environment - specifically we need to be able to give a range of seastate values to specify the range of operating conditions that the tasks solutions will be tested against.

In the current default branch the wave field is specified as a summation of N regular waves where the amplitude, period and direction of each wave component are specified directly - see [#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/wamv\_gazebo/urdf/dynamics/wamv\_gazebo\_dynamics\_plugin.xacro](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/wamv_gazebo/urdf/dynamics/wamv_gazebo_dynamics_plugin.xacro)

In the proposed synchronized physics visualization \(see PR [#78 ](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/78/issue-23-coordinate-the-physics-and/diff)\) the wave field is specified like so…

```
./devel/lib/asv_wave_sim_gazebo_plugins/WaveMsgPublisher \
  --number 3 \
  --scale 2 \
  --angle 0.4 \
  --direction -1 -1 \
  --steepness 1 \
  --period 7 \
  --amplitude .1
```

where the properties of the individual wave components are determined as described [here](https://developer.nvidia.com/gpugems/GPUGems/gpugems_ch01.html). 

After we integrate the physics/visual synchronization \(see issue [#23](#!/osrf/vrx/issues/23/coordinate-the-physics-and-visualization)\) we need to determine a reasonable way to describe the range of seastates that will be use for task evaluation.
content.html:
For the purposes of the competition we need to be able to specify the wave conditions (seastate) in the environment - specifically we need to be able to give a range of seastate values to specify the range of operating conditions that the tasks solutions will be tested against.

In the current default branch the wave field is specified as a summation of N regular waves where the amplitude, period and direction of each wave component are specified directly - see #!/osrf/vrx/src/default/wamv_gazebo/urdf/dynamics/wamv_gazebo_dynamics_plugin.xacro

In the proposed synchronized physics visualization (see PR #78 ) the wave field is specified like so…

./devel/lib/asv_wave_sim_gazebo_plugins/WaveMsgPublisher \
  --number 3 \
  --scale 2 \
  --angle 0.4 \
  --direction -1 -1 \
  --steepness 1 \
  --period 7 \
  --amplitude .1

where the properties of the individual wave components are determined as described here.

After we integrate the physics/visual synchronization (see issue #23) we need to determine a reasonable way to describe the range of seastates that will be use for task evaluation.

values.title: Buoyancy plugin improvement for flat ocean and standard shapes

content.raw:
Currently the [buoyancy\_gazebo\_plugin.cc](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/usv_gazebo_plugins/src/buoyancy_gazebo_plugin.cc) is used to provide a vertical buoyancy force to objects at or near the surface of the water such as course elements like buoys, markers, obstacles, etc.  As an example see the surmark950400 [model.sdf.](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/vrx_gazebo/models/surmark950400/model.sdf)  In the current implementation each model plugin is independently configured with

* water level in z direction, gazebo coordinates
* drag
* water density
* cross-sectional-area
* height
* center of volume 

The effective buoyancy force is calculated as simply the product of the cross-sectional-area and the relative z displacement of the object and the water level. This method models any link as a shape of constant cross-sectional area  for a finite height object.  Also, the buoyancy object is always considered to be oriented perpendicular to the water surface.

Consider revising the plugin to enable specifying simple geometry\(ies\).  For example, the model.sdf for the surmark950400 marker might look something like…

```
<plugin name="BuoyancyPlugin" filename="libbuoyancy_gazebo_plugin.so">
      <fluid_density>1000</fluid_density>
      <fluid_level>0.0</fluid_level>
      <fluid_drag>5.0</fluid_drag>
      <element name="buoyancy_inner">
        <link_name>link</link_name>
        <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <radius>0.15</radius>
            <length>1.18</length>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
      </element>
      <element name="buoyancy_outer">
        <link_name>link</link_name>
        <pose>0 0 -0.31 0 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <radius>0.24</radius>
            <length>0.2</length>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
      </element>
 
    </plugin>
```

‌

* Should be able to support box, cylinder and sphere geometries.
* Should be able to support multiple “elements” for each model
* Should take into account the orientation of each geometry element when calculating the center of buoyancy - where the force is applied.

Will need to put together some simple tests to verify the implementation.

Follow-on work will be to have the ability to get the instantaneous water height at the object location to include the wave field, but that will need to wait until after we address [issue #23](#!/osrf/vrx/issues/23/coordinate-the-physics-and-visualization).

Currently the buoyancy_gazebo_plugin.cc is used to provide a vertical buoyancy force to objects at or near the surface of the water such as course elements like buoys, markers, obstacles, etc. As an example see the surmark950400 model.sdf. In the current implementation each model plugin is independently configured with

  • water level in z direction, gazebo coordinates
  • drag
  • water density
  • cross-sectional-area
  • height
  • center of volume

The effective buoyancy force is calculated as simply the product of the cross-sectional-area and the relative z displacement of the object and the water level. This method models any link as a shape of constant cross-sectional area for a finite height object. Also, the buoyancy object is always considered to be oriented perpendicular to the water surface.

Consider revising the plugin to enable specifying simple geometry(ies). For example, the model.sdf for the surmark950400 marker might look something like…

<plugin name="BuoyancyPlugin" filename="libbuoyancy_gazebo_plugin.so">
      <fluid_density>1000</fluid_density>
      <fluid_level>0.0</fluid_level>
      <fluid_drag>5.0</fluid_drag>
      <element name="buoyancy_inner">
        <link_name>link</link_name>
        <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <radius>0.15</radius>
            <length>1.18</length>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
      </element>
      <element name="buoyancy_outer">
        <link_name>link</link_name>
        <pose>0 0 -0.31 0 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <radius>0.24</radius>
            <length>0.2</length>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
      </element>

    </plugin>

‌

  • Should be able to support box, cylinder and sphere geometries.
  • Should be able to support multiple “elements” for each model
  • Should take into account the orientation of each geometry element when calculating the center of buoyancy - where the force is applied.

Will need to put together some simple tests to verify the implementation.

Follow-on work will be to have the ability to get the instantaneous water height at the object location to include the wave field, but that will need to wait until after we address issue #23.

values.title: Propulsion: Adding vectored thrust capability

content.raw:
Currently our [propulsion configuration](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/PropulsionConfiguration) options only include thrusters where the thrust angle, relative to the WAM-V body-frame, is fixed.  Some RobotX teams design the stern thrusters so that they can articulate, changing the thrust angle - as illustrated by the “Differential Thrust. Variable Angle” case in the [propulsion configuration](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/PropulsionConfiguration) wiki.

We’d like to extend both the [usv\_gazebo\_thrust\_plugin](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/usv_gazebo_plugins/src/usv_gazebo_thrust_plugin.cc) Gazebo model plugin and the [engine.xacro](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/wamv_description/urdf/engine.xacro) model so that users can change the thrust angle via a ROS API.  

* The thrust plugin would subscribe to a ROS topic, e.g., “left\_ thrust\_angle”, that would set the angular displacement of the thruster.

    * The angle, in radians, would be relative to the nominal thruster attitude.
    
* The configuration should allow for angle limits \(e.g., \+/- pi/2\) to be set.
* A new rotation joint should be included in the engine model to facilitate the rotation

    * The plugin would also set the joint rotation so that the visual model reflects the vectored thrust.
content.html:
Currently our propulsion configuration options only include thrusters where the thrust angle, relative to the WAM-V body-frame, is fixed. Some RobotX teams design the stern thrusters so that they can articulate, changing the thrust angle - as illustrated by the “Differential Thrust. Variable Angle” case in the propulsion configuration wiki.

We’d like to extend both the usv_gazebo_thrust_plugin Gazebo model plugin and the engine.xacro model so that users can change the thrust angle via a ROS API.

  • The thrust plugin would subscribe to a ROS topic, e.g., “left_ thrust_angle”, that would set the angular displacement of the thruster.

    • The angle, in radians, would be relative to the nominal thruster attitude.

  • The configuration should allow for angle limits (e.g., +/- pi/2) to be set.

  • A new rotation joint should be included in the engine model to facilitate the rotation

    • The plugin would also set the joint rotation so that the visual model reflects the vectored thrust.

values.title: Propulsion: Allowing for YAML based configuration

content.raw:
The simulation supports a fixed number of [propulsion configuration](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/PropulsionConfiguration) options.  Another way for the user to specify the configuration of the thrusters is to allow for a YAML configuration setting to specify the type, location and orientation of thrusters - similar to the way sensor configuration is handled in PR [#99](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/99/yaml-sensor-configuration/diff) Yaml sensor configuration.

For the VRX competition teams would be limited to no more than four thrusters, but would have flexibility as to where they are located.  Note: we should probably specify that the roll and the pitch of the thrusters must be zero.

Optionally, we could consider having a few different thrusters, e.g., a high-force thruster and a low-force thruster.  Teams could only have a maximum of two high-force thrusters and two low-force thrusters.  Perhaps overly complicate?
content.html:
The simulation supports a fixed number of propulsion configuration options. Another way for the user to specify the configuration of the thrusters is to allow for a YAML configuration setting to specify the type, location and orientation of thrusters - similar to the way sensor configuration is handled in PR #99 Yaml sensor configuration.

For the VRX competition teams would be limited to no more than four thrusters, but would have flexibility as to where they are located. Note: we should probably specify that the roll and the pitch of the thrusters must be zero.

Optionally, we could consider having a few different thrusters, e.g., a high-force thruster and a low-force thruster. Teams could only have a maximum of two high-force thrusters and two low-force thrusters. Perhaps overly complicate?

values.title: Propulsion: Refining the thrust model

content.raw:
The thruster plugin implements a mapping from command values to force.   A linear and non-linear mapping is available \(see the [Theory of Operation](https://github.com/bsb808/robotx_docs/blob/master/theoryofoperation/theory_of_operation.pdf) document\).  The default non-linear mapping uses parameters to reproduce the empirical thruster curve measured by the FAU team.  We should do some investigation to determine how representative that thruster model is - how does it compare to the thrusters used by other teams.  

This would probably require looking into the RobotX documentation provided by the 2016 and 2018 teams to see what variety there is in terms of thruster implementation.   It might also be worthwhile to engage with the VRX teams for 2019 to see if they have more information on their thruster behavior that might be useful in determining a model that is generally acceptable to all.

For the purposes of VRX, we can probably get away with a model that is a best-case scenario - generating high-force - so that teams aren’t artificially limited by the control authority.
content.html:
The thruster plugin implements a mapping from command values to force. A linear and non-linear mapping is available (see the Theory of Operation document). The default non-linear mapping uses parameters to reproduce the empirical thruster curve measured by the FAU team. We should do some investigation to determine how representative that thruster model is - how does it compare to the thrusters used by other teams.

This would probably require looking into the RobotX documentation provided by the 2016 and 2018 teams to see what variety there is in terms of thruster implementation. It might also be worthwhile to engage with the VRX teams for 2019 to see if they have more information on their thruster behavior that might be useful in determining a model that is generally acceptable to all.

For the purposes of VRX, we can probably get away with a model that is a best-case scenario - generating high-force - so that teams aren’t artificially limited by the control authority.

values.title: Issue#99 wamv compliance

content.raw:
Organization:

VRX compliance rules need to be determined. How many of each type of sensor is allowed, and where can these sensors be place relative to the wamv.

Implementation:

The python file vrx\_gazebo/src/vrx\_gazebo\_python/generator\_scripts/sensor\_config/compliance.py \(see/modify implementation by vrx\_gazebo/src/vrx\_gazebo\_python/generator\_scripts/sensor\_config/configure\_sensors.py\) needs to be fleshed  out to reject unreasonable sensor configurations as defined by the VRX  compliance rules. Currently, no configuration will be rejected based on compliance violation.

values.title: Wind plugin moved to world plugin

content.raw:
Currently, the wind  plugin \(wamv\_gazebo\_wind\_plugin\) is a model plugin \(attached to the wamv for VRX\). This was done as a way to lower required computation\(so the forces of the wind are only calculated on the wamv\).

These plugins should be changed to world plugins for at least 3 reasons:

1. Wind is not a property of the wamv, it is properties of the world.
2. With the current solution, a new wamv needs to be generated for each desired change in wind conditions. This is messy.
3. The current solution has no expand ability for multiple model effects at the same time. ie: for the docking challenge we may want both the wamv and the dock to experience effects of the same wind.

Desired outcome:

Wind is a world plugin initiated by xacro with lists of models the wind will effect \(as well as parameters to describe the models \(number are currently hard coded\)\).

The plugin searches the model list on every update until it has all the models included on the instantiation list.

The plugin then applies the appropriate forces to the models.
content.html:
Currently, the wind plugin (wamv_gazebo_wind_plugin) is a model plugin (attached to the wamv for VRX). This was done as a way to lower required computation(so the forces of the wind are only calculated on the wamv).

These plugins should be changed to world plugins for at least 3 reasons:

  1. Wind is not a property of the wamv, it is properties of the world.
  2. With the current solution, a new wamv needs to be generated for each desired change in wind conditions. This is messy.
  3. The current solution has no expand ability for multiple model effects at the same time. ie: for the docking challenge we may want both the wamv and the dock to experience effects of the same wind.

Desired outcome:

Wind is a world plugin initiated by xacro with lists of models the wind will effect (as well as parameters to describe the models (number are currently hard coded)).

The plugin searches the model list on every update until it has all the models included on the instantiation list.

The plugin then applies the appropriate forces to the models.
